Topic: Trains

Just returned from Italy. For anyone traveling to more than one city, just keep in mind travel time and possible delays. Also keep in mind luggage.

A few things:

We took 4 trains to different cities, 2 were delayed. Naples to Rome was delayed by an hour. Florence to Venice was delayed by 4 hours.

All the trains were a little different but I’m telling you it’s hard to travel with a lot of luggage. Florence to Venice there were sections at the end of the car we were able to put big luggage but it wasn’t very big. All the other trains we needed to put it on top- including large suit cases, so you will need to be able to lift it up over your head. There were a few spaces I could put in between the seats but many were taken by other passengers’ luggage.

The train station in Perugia was definitely hard with luggage - we had to carry it up and down stairs. Our other stations were major cities, but I imagine other stations that aren’t as major can be similar to this.

It’s been said in other posts, but they only add the train gate a little before it departs. My suggestion is to be waiting and looking at the screen and ready to go immediately when it’s posted.

Anyway. I just wanted to post in case it helps anyone. Traveling without really knowing how it will be when you are there is stressful so I hope it helps a little.

I want to share what I think may be helpful for a family travelling to Italy. My husband and I (in our 50's), along with our 2 sons (21 and 18) spent 11 very full days in Italy. We flew from Canada direct to Frankfurt, Germany then got on a train to Zermatt, Switzerland where we spent 1 night. It was a quaint little town with a cog train to take you to the Matterhorn! AMAZING!
From there we traveled by fast train, trenitalia, through Italy. When booking our trip, I wanted hotels that were in the town centers so we could immerse ourselves in Italian culture and walk or hop on a bus, metro or cab to get around. We didn't want fancy or pools or anything like that. Just clean, authentic, air conditioned, great location. In Rome we stayed in a former monastery called Casa Cappuccini. It was VERY plain but clean, great location. We had a family room with 1 queen bed and 2 twin beds. AC worked great and it had an elevator, very friendly staff, no breakfast included but a restaurant right across the street. It was also steps away from a taxi stand, the metro train and the hop on hop off bus stop. And only a walk to lots of restaurants, trevi fountain. If you want fancy, this is not for you but for us it was perfect and we would stay again.
Next, we went to Sorrento and stayed at Hotel del Corso. This hotel was in the center of town and a short walk from the train station, the town square, lots of shops and restaurants, and the marina where you can pay to go to a beach club or catch a ferry or boat to other destinations. This hotel was also very old but clean, had an elevator and AC. We loved the authentic Italian feel, the owners were super kind, helpful and friendly and buffet style breakfast was included. There was a washer and dryer on site as well that you could pay to use which I did as it was near the end of our trip! This hotel had a beautiful terrace overlooking the street and town Square. Bfast was served here. At this hotel we opted for 2 rooms, one with a queen bed and one with 2 twins. Both very clean. I hope this post will help someone looking for a similar experience. Our goal was to really experience Italy, the history, the food, the people, the charm and everything that makes it so different from modern North America.
If you are looking for modern or to spend a lot of time at your hotel, these options are probably not for you. I hope you love Italy as much as we did! 🇮🇹

I’m sharing a few things that may help others from my own experience in Italy these last two weeks (Rome, Florence, Venice, positano, sorrento, capri, Milan and lake como).

1. Pack light. If you think you packed light, pack even lighter. Wash and reuse and/or buy there (yes they have everything you need).

2. Pack clothes that dry easily. Dryers are not common. If needed ask hotel/Airbnb for paid laundry service.

3. The main tourist places speak English but a small gesture of Italian helps with a good experience for all. I found that my Spanish (very similar to Italian) got me pretty far.

4. Uber app is available in most places but difficult to confirm a driver. The metro (subway) is great. Taxis work well here and lots have bike/e-bike/scooter options. If you’re going somewhere far I’d suggest to prebook a driver.

5. I have T-Mobile and I didn’t get reception anywhere. It was difficult to navigate without use of my phone. If you’re the same I suggest having a plan with routes/train lines etc before you leave your hotel/Airbnb so you’re not wandering around looking for WiFi.
